text: Patient: I need two weeks off. Doctor: Yeah. No, no, no, we’ll figure it out. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s just keep things moving and we’ll figure it out. Patient: So J___ told me that his promise to you is he said he’ll get me squared away medically and then - Doctor: Yes, and then it’s time for us to take over! (chuckles) Patient: Yeah. ___ called me last night. He said we’re taking a break in oncology and we’re going to do some medicine. And I said okay. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: That really made me feel good, for you, too, and for me. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Because I was like “You’ve got to do that or I get derailed from what I have to do.” Patient: Right. Doctor: So he’s on it.

text: Patient: So that be ah ah the police looking for her and now they found and press charges. I don’t know her number. I don’t want her around me. I want nobody around me no more. Doctor: hhh Okay because… Patient: I don’t want no one… Doctor: …you know what the pharmacist said now. Patient: Yes I’ve been going to H_____. Doctor: So you’re going to H_____ Pharmacy now? Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Okay that’s where you switched to? Patient: That’s where I’ve been going and then try to talk to uh I tried to talk to her Monday when I came in I can’t think of her name, H____. I talked to her. She said Mr. F____ you haven’t done anything wrong. And I said I know it. So you know what I’m saying? Somebody was stealing from me. So I said why couldn’t I -I can’t come here. That’s any policy. Any pharmacy you go to that I’ve ever been to, you have to have your ID. Couldn’t anyone come up there and get your stuff. And then I had told them two weeks before. Doctor: But you’ve never had ID for a long time and they were doing you a special favor right… Patient: No I… Doctor: …by giving you. Now you have ID. Patient: I’ve been having it, doctor, I’ve been disappointed though uh when I put, two weeks after I put in there do not let anyone come and pick up my medication if it’s not me. text: Patient: I don’t know what you think about that because that lesion is right where the nerve is pinched and I don’t know if he goes in there and stirs things up uh… Doctor: Well. Patient: He’s he’s not for sure yet. The last time I saw him he said I don’t want to open a whole can of worms and I told him if you can’t make it better… I can live with it, I can live with it. Doctor: Although their main reasoning was that there was disc issues and arthritis more the bigger problem for the nerve than… Patient: Right. Doctor: …the cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: and… Patient: But the cancer… Doctor: You know but at the time the cancer was also acting up so I said let me treat the cancer. Patient: Right. Doctor: Let’s see if that makes any change. text: Patient: So what’s goin’ on, so what’s goin’ on with my bones? Doctor: Nothin’. Patient: He just said that somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: No. I didn’t say anything. Patient: The other doctor that came in before him, before Dr. P_, said somethin’ was goin’ on with my bones. Healthcare Professional 1: Oh. Doctor: G_? Healthcare Professional 1: He had progression on his bone scan and CAT scan. That’s what he might have gone through. Doctor: Oh, could be. But his bones are not progressed. It’s just the, um, lymph nodes. (Pause) Patient: No. Doctor: I’m the one bringin’ it up because I see it on the scan. Oh!! We gotta do something. We gotta do something. But, from a functional day-to-day, it’s not really buggin’ you. If you were peeing poop, it would bug you. You would know it. It would frighten the heck out of everybody, but that’s not what’s happening. So, here’s a chance where we can proactively think about it and not wait until it’s an emergency. Patient: I’m not peeing poop.

text: Patient: Yeah. And and that gets you more. Doctor: I know. text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, then and so, all that works from a time frame. Then, the counts, the next week which you’re getting - I don’t know if that’s for the study or - then you can get that at LabCorp. That’s gonna come to us. Uh, we don’t do much with that. That’s more if you call us, and you say, “Hey, you know, I have a fever.” We can look at those blood tests and say, “Hey, it’s low. So, you should go to the hospital.” Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now, it’s normal. You’re like everybody else. Just take your Tylenol or whatever. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay, and we’ll get you a chemo teaching class. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So, uh, they’ll just tell you what to worry about, what not to worry about, what fevers we worry about, what numbers to call, uh, what you can eat, what you don’t eat sometimes. I don’t know what the class really is about. Patient: Okay. Family Member: So, S_ had, um, he was getting chemo, he had a bathroom that nobody was supposed to use. Doctor: They’ll talk to you about that and teach it in the class, but I don’t think that’s an issue. Family Member: Okay.

text: Patient: Wow, wow. Doctor: So, then the next day when, you know, it was Monday afternoon my patient called and he goes okay, we’re never gonna do that again. I’m like, because he got his dose like Friday Patient: Right. Doctor: and then he traveled Sunday and I was like okay, that will teach you not to do that. So, now, I reported that back so now every single time, and they didn’t give him the card because they’re like it’s so low you won’t Patient: You won’t know yeah. Doctor: set off anything, you’ll be fine. After that incident, everybody gets a card. That’s a longwinded way of saying, everybody gets a card. Patient: Everybody gets card, okay. Now is that here? Doctor: Yeah. So, there is a Dr. M____. We’re gonna write this down for you guys Patient: Okay. Alright. Doctor: and then we’ll make the referral but just so you know we’ll start the prior authorization process so by the time you see him we’ve got everything under way and then he’ll just take over. Patient: Okay and then I see you after or during? Doctor: Right, so like I’m kind of just hovering because we’re trying not to add more work.

text: Patient: That the cancer is shrinking. Doctor: So if his PSA drops. Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So if he’s not on a clinical trial, I don’t get new pictures. Family Member: Ah, okay. Okay. text: Patient: Yeah. Doctor: I’m not sure there’s more side effects; it’s just sort of we just have to put them out there, talk about them more. Patient: Yes. Doctor: You know chemotherapy has its own set of side effects Patient: Right. Doctor: But we have what the known benefits potentially are, whereas the clinical trials—we don’t know the benefits. Family Member: Yeah, uh hum. Doctor: We know a lot about the side effects. Family Member: Well with having chemotherapy, would that be, I know it’s not the same drug, but the same effect like I had chemotherapy for breast cancer? Doctor: Yes, we use one drug. We use Taxotere. So I don’t which ones you got. Family Member: I had Adriamycin and Cytoxan. Doctor: Yeah, it’s a little bit different.

text: Healthcare Professional: Yeah, she doesn’t start I.V.’s. They have to have the I.V. tech start them. Doctor: for chemo. HCP Okay, I’m going to take these to K____. Patient: Uh you know if you’re uh if you’re driving around in a Mercedes, the least you could do is order a nice pen. (conversation in background) Doctor: Oh my turnover of pens is crazy. I never have fancy pens because I lose them. Patient: Your husband has a bunch of ‘em. They have their nice pens. Doctor: Oh my gosh; I didn’t know that. Family Member: He said he hides them. Doctor: I guess I don’t even. I didn’t even know that. Patient: Oh yeah, because I took one when I was down there and the guy (she gets after me for swiping people’s pens) Doctor: So mine are, you’re allowed to swipe. (Laughs) Patient: Yeah, you can throw these away. (chuckles) Doctor: Well I use them so much; I mean I run out of ink and then I need to be able to toss and then move on to the next one.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
